description: Stigma scale: average score of 6 stigma items; higher scores indicate higher stigma.

name: KB_B_AnyUse_Correct
description: Anyone who uses opioids long-term for pain has an opioid addiction [False]: disagreement coded as "correct"
encodings: 0.0=Incorrect|1.0=Correct

name: KB_E_QuitAnytime_Correct
description: A person struggling with opioid use disorder/addiction can quit using anytime if they choose [False]: disagreement coded as "correct"
encodings: 0.0=Incorrect|1.0=Correct

name: KB_I_RockBottom_Correct
description: A person struggling with opioid use disorder/addiction must hit rock bottom before they are ready to accept treatment [False]: disagreement coded as "correct"
encodings: 0.0=Incorrect|1.0=Correct

name: KB_J_EasyFind_Correct
description: It is easy to find good opioid use disorder treatment [False]: disagreement coded as "correct"
encodings: 0.0=Incorrect|1.0=Correct

name: KB_N_MedAbuse_Correct
description: Medication for opioid use disorder (e.g., methadone, buprenorphine/suboxone, or naltrexone/vivitrol) is just substituting one form of drug abuse for another type of drug abuse [False]: disagreement coded as "correct"
encodings: 0.0=Incorrect|1.0=Correct

name: KB_A_Definition_Correct
description: Opioid addiction is defined by a person continuing to use opioids despite negative consequences [True]: agreement coded as correct
encodings: 0.0=Incorrect|1.0=Correct

name: KB_F_StopBreathing_Correct
description: When misused, opioids can slow your breathing or even cause you to stop breathing entirely and lead to an overdose or death [True]: agreement coded as correct
encodings: 0.0=Incorrect|1.0=Correct

name: KB_G_Recover_Correct
description: Evidence-based treatments for opioid use disorder can recover people from opioid addiction [True]: agreement coded as correct
encodings: 0.0=Incorrect|1.0=Correct

name: KB_H_MedicalCondition_Correct
description: Opioid use disorder is a medical condition like other chronic health conditions [True]: agreement coded as correct
encodings: 0.0=Incorrect|1.0=Correct

name: KB_K_FDA_Correct
description: The FDA has approved medications that are effective in treating opioid use disorder/addiction [True]: agreement coded as correct
encodings: 0.0=Incorrect|1.0=Correct

name: Policy_Attitudes_Scale
description: Policy attitudes scale score from average of eight items. Higher scores indicate more support for policies benefitting those with OUD.

name: Discrimination_Scale_Score
description: Acceptance of discrimination scale score from average of four items. Higher scores indicate more acceptance of discrimination.

name: KnowledgeScore_new
description: Sum of 10 knowledge-based items, with higher scores indicating more knowledge.

name: Criminality_Scale_Score
description: Perceptions of criminality scale score. Average of five items with higher scores indicating more perceived criminality toward those with OUD.

name: PS_A_Medicaid
description: I favor expanding Medicaid insurance benefits for low income families to provide coverage for treatment of opioid use disorders/addiction problems, including addiction to prescription pain medications

name: PS_B_Naloxone
description: I favor making naloxone (also known as 'Narcan'), a medication that can quickly reverse the effects of a person experiencing an opioid overdose, widely available and affordable without a prescription

name: PS_C_Mandatory
description: I believe that making drug treatment mandatory is an effective way to help people with an opioid use disorder

name: PS_D_GovSpend
description: I favor increasing government spending to improve treatment of opioid use disorder/addiction

name: DS_E_Schools
description: High schools and colleges should be allowed to dismiss or expel a person with an opioid use disorder/addiction

name: DS_F_Physicians
description: Physicians and other healthcare providers should be allowed to refuse to treat a person with an opioid use disorder/addiction

name: DS_G_Employers
description: Employers should be allowed to deny employment to a person with a current opioid use disorder/addiction

name: DS_H_Landlords
description: Landlords should be allowed to deny housing to a person with a current opioid use disorder/addiction

name: PS_I_SeekMedical
description: I favor passing laws to protect people from criminal charges for drug crimes if they seek medical help for experiencing an opioid/prescription pain medication problem

name: PS_J_JailHealth
description: I believe that incarceration/jail is an effective way to improve the health of people with an opioid use disorder

name: PS_K_JailOverdose
description: I believe that incarceration/jail is an effective way to reduce the risk of overdosing for people with an opioid use disorder

name: PS_L_JailTreatment
description: I believe that people in jail/prison with an opioid use disorder/addiction problem should get access to medication for opioid use disorder (e.g., methadone, buprenorphine, or naltrexone)

name: SS_E_Dangerous
description: People with a current addiction to opioids/prescription pain medications are more dangerous than the general population

name: SS_F_Trust
description: A person who is currently addicted to opioids/prescription pain medication cannot be trusted

name: SS_A_HistoryWork
description: I would be willing to have a person with a past history of opioid use disorder/addiction start working closely with me on a job

name: SS_B_HistoryMarry
description: I am comfortable having a person with a past history of opioid use disorder/addiction marry into my family

name: SS_C_CurrentWork
description: I would be willing to have a person with a current opioid use disorder/addiction start working closely with me on a job

name: SS_D_CurrentMarry
description: I would be comfortable having a person with a current opioid use disorder/addiction marry into my family

name: CS_A_Obtain
description: I favor arresting and prosecuting people who obtain opioids/pain medication from sources other than a medical provider

name: CS_B_Use
description: I favor arresting and prosecuting people who use opioids in a way not as prescribed by a doctor

name: CS_C_SentencedJail
description: People found guilty of misuse of opioids/prescription pain medication need to be sentenced to jail or prison

name: CS_D_IncarceratedAccess
description: Individuals who are incarcerated with an opioid use disorder/addiction should get access to evidence-based treatment while incarcerated

name: CS_E_ParoleAccess
description: Individuals who are on parole or probation with an opioid use disorder/addiction should get access to evidence-based treatment

name: KB_A_Definition
description: Opioid addiction is defined by a person continuing to use opioids despite negative consequences

name: KB_B_AnyUse
description: Anyone who uses opioids long-term for pain has an opioid addiction

name: KB_C_SelfControl
description: Most people who develop and/or struggle with opioid use disorder/addiction lack self-control

name: KB_D_MoralFail
description: Misuse of opioids is a moral failing

name: KB_E_QuitAnytime
description: A person struggling with opioid use disorder/addiction can quit using anytime if they choose

name: KB_F_StopBreathing
description: When misused, opioids can slow your breathing or even cause you to stop breathing entirely and lead to an overdose or death

description: Opioid use disorder is a medical condition like other chronic health conditions

name: KB_I_RockBottom
description: A person struggling with opioid use disorder/addiction must hit rock bottom before they are ready to accept treatment

description: It is easy to find good opioid use disorder treatment

name: KB_K_FDA
description: The FDA has approved medications that are effective in treating opioid use disorder/addiction

name: KB_L_JailHelps
description: Jailing someone with an opioid use disorder for at least a few days will help them by reducing their risk for an overdose

name: KB_M_MedHoax
description: Medication for opioid use disorder (e.g., methadone, buprenorphine, or naltrexone) is a hoax

description: Medication for opioid use disorder (e.g., methadone, buprenorphine/suboxone, or naltrexone/vivitrol) is just substituting one form of drug abuse for another type of drug abuse

description: People with an opioid use disorder/addiction need long-term treatment with medications

description: Zscore(Criminality_Scale_Score)  Perceptions of criminality scale score. Average of five items with higher scores indicating more perceived criminality toward those with OUD.

name: ZSco05
description: Zscore(DisregardofOUD)  Disregard of OUD factor analysis scale, with higher scores indicating more disregard of OUD as a medical condition

name: ZSS_F_Trust_Bi
description: Zscore:  [A person who is currently addicted to opioids/prescription pain medication cannot be trusted.] Do you disagree or agree with the following statements?

name: INCOME4
description: Household income (4 categories)
